b'We're raising awareness for @unitednations Goal #6, Clean Water and Sanitation, through our partnership with @togetherbandofficial. The scale and impact of our global water crisis is shocking. 1) Achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all 
2) Achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all - ending open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations. 
3) Improve water quality (by reducing pollution, eliminating dumping and minimizing release of hazardous chemicals and materials)
4) Increase water-use efficiency ensuring sustainable withdrawals and supply of freshwater

b'Alaska is seeing the accelerating effects of climate change. How do we know? Otters are disappearing. Have we sparked your interest? While otters may seemingly have little to do with climate change, they play an important role in balancing their native ecosystem. In Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s Aleutian Islands, sea otters have been hunted to near-extinction by humans. As a result, sea urchins are destroying the area\xe2\x80\x99s massive limestone reefs. How? The reefs are built by algae, which develop a protective outer limestone skeleton to keep predators at bay. With rising ocean temperatures, however, this process has become more difficult, exposing the algae to predators. With their natural predators, otters, being nearly extinct, sea urchins can graze on the reefs freely and unthreatened, thereby depleting it. 

Our actions, like hunting sea otters can have serious and far-reaching consequences on our environment. Tap the link in our bio to learn about our efforts to make a positive impact. 
Source: Loss of sea otters accelerating the effects of climate change October 2020

b'When we think about pollution in our oceans, we often think about plastic garbage and nasty chemicals. But did you know there\xe2\x80\x99s another polluter threating life under water? It\xe2\x80\x99s noise. \nAll the sounds made by human activities are called ocean noise. When noise levels go up, they can reduce the ability of animals to find potential mates, communicate with other group members, their offspring, and avoid predators. Luckily, noise is easier and quicker to reduce than ocean acidification or fossil-fuel use. Many international organizations, companies and countries are taking action to move into quieter technologies to reduce ocean noise. Let\xe2\x80\x99s raise awareness for this problem and spread the word. As more people learn about this issue, more people and governments will act to keep our oceans in good health.'

b'Today, around 55% of the world\xe2\x80\x99s population lives in cities. By 2050, that will rise to about 70%. So how are cities developing to accommodate this surge in urban living? Around the world, cities are taking innovative approaches to ensure the safety and sustainability of its inhabitants. How? 
1. Sponge cities:  in Singapore, green spaces are being introduced to neighborhoods to help\xe2\x80\x9csoak up floodwater\xe2\x80\x9d. 
2. Vertical forests: architects in Milan found a clever way to fit a forest that would span three and a half football pitches in the city. How? They developed a forest vertically, as opposed to horizontally, on two residential tower blocks. 
3. 20-minute neighborhood: Melbourne is leading the way in ensuring that everything someone may need to live a happy, healthy life is within easy reach. This includes shops, business services, education and leisure facilities, thereby minimizing commutes. 
The @unitednations Sustainable Development Goal #11, Sustainable Cities and communities, outlines the importance of ensuring a sustainable urban future. To explore goal #11 and the other @unitednations Sustainable Development Goals, tap the link in our bio. 

Source:
https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2020/09/cities-sustainability-innovation-global-goals/'

b'When talking about climate change solutions, seaweed is rarely mentioned. There\xe2\x80\x99s a common misconception that forests are the best way to fight climate change. b'Do you want to have a positive impact on climate change but not sure how to get started? Here are three smart ways to get started:.

3. Unplug electronic devices when they aren't in use. Just because a device or appliance appears to be off doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean it\xe2\x80\x99s not using power. About a quarter of all residential energy consumption is used on devices in idle power mode, which means \xe2\x80\x9csleep mode\xe2\x80\x9d is costing upward of $19 billion in electricity bills. Things like your cable box, laptop, and even your speakers may be using almost as much power when they are off but plugged in.
